The High Schools of the Hall County School District are working very hard to do their best to create a graduation ceremony that honors our class of 2020. Obviously, the current circumstances due to the pandemic prevent us from having traditional ceremonies. This is heartbreaking for seniors and their families, and we hurt with them.

There are rumors of schools cancelling graduation. Please know that is not the case. Ceremonies are moving forward on the dates previously shared by the district, and the high schools are working hard on their plans. Some have shared what they have developed thus far, but no plan is finished. Principals and their graduation teams are still getting feedback from seniors and exploring options.

If you have questions regarding your school's graduation plan, please contact the principal.

We are proud of our Hall County Seniors. They are a strong and resilient group. The aim of every high school is to provide a ceremony that honors them while protecting the health of students, families, staff members, and the community.

Another Hall County student giving their time and energy to provide and support others.

For the past month, Carson Whitt, a junior at Johnson High School, has been making masks for the Hall County School District employees charged with distributing meals in our communities. So far, Carson has donated 100 masks to Chicopee Woods, Tadmore, Riverbend, and White Sulphur Elementary Schools.

The project originally started as a way to earn his National Honor Society service hours, and as Carson put it, "...and to do a good deed at the same time." Since then, it has become much more to Carson.

Carson says none of this would be possible were it not for his grandmother, Judy Whitt. She does the majority of the sewing machine operation, and without her, it would take double the time to make the masks. Carson says, "She always pushes me to be the best person I can be and she has greatly encouraged me on our mask project."

Many thanks, Carson and Ms. Judy Whitt!

For the past month, Carson Whitt, a junior at Johnson High School, has been making masks for the Hall County School District employees charged with distributing meals in our communities. So far, Carson has donated 100 masks to Chicopee Woods, Tadmore, Riverbend, and White Sulphur Elementary Schools.

The project originally started as a way to earn his National Honor Society service hours, and as Carson put it, "...and to do a good deed at the same time." Since then, it has become much more to Carson.

Carson says none of this would be possible were it not for his grandmother, Judy Whitt. She does the majority of the sewing machine operation, and without her, it would take double the time to make the masks. Carson says, "She always pushes me to be the best person I can be and she has greatly encouraged me on our mask project."

Many thanks, Carson and Ms. Judy Whitt!

This week's Leading and Reading Spotlight is Cathryn Sawyer, Assistant principal of Curriculum and Instruction at Johnson High School.

What are you currently reading? Please give a brief blurb about your book.

"Just Mercy- A Story of Justice and Redemption," by Bryan Stevenson
"It's a Story of a Harvard grad who goes to the deep south and sets up legal clinics to help create a system of fairness for marginalized people (often children) who have been falsely or harshly sentenced."

What do you enjoy reading?

"I enjoy Murder mysteries and biographies. I particularly love books that take place outside- the Joe Picket murder series in Wyoming or books about hiking- the Appalachian Trail, the Pacific Trail, or other places."

Why do you read?

"I read many educational and instructional books on literacy, differentiation and education, but I also read for enjoyment and relaxation. When I read, I feel that I am wherever the characters are- so I hike, find the bad guys, and I travel along with the characters."

This week's Leading and Reading Spotlight is David Wagner, assistant principal and athletic director at West Hall High School.

What are you currently reading?

"Right now I am reading DUTCH – A Memoir of Ronald Reagan. I literally just started this book a few days ago. Ronald Reagan is the first President I remember as a child, and quite honestly was a man my father admired and loved. He was President of the United States when I was 6 to 14 years of age, and from my early teenage viewpoint one of the greats. He was a man that my father felt like united a nation and stood firm on the things our country stands for. Things I feel like are getting lost in our world at times. I look forward to diving into his memoirs and finding out more about the man behind the Presidency."

What do you enjoy reading?

"Honestly I don’t prefer one genre over another. I read based on my mood and what strikes my interest."

Why do you read?

"I was given the gift of the ability to read by my parents and some wonderful teachers in East Tennessee. It should never be wasted."

This week's Leading and Reading Spotlight is Dr. Renee Carey, Assistant Principal at East Hall High School.

What are you currently reading?

"Little Fires Everywhere by Celeste Ng (the title reminds me of my life as an AP). The novel is the second one by the author. She explores social tensions and family dynamics in a small Ohio town. It begins with a house fire and a death incorporating many small plot lines that represent the “little fires everywhere”. A movie is currently available on Hulu, but I do not allow myself to watch a movie before reading the book."

What do you enjoy reading?

"I enjoy books that have universal and timeless themes. I also like biographies and autobiographies. I often choose books by new authors because they have a fresh perspective on writing."

Why do you read?

"I read to learn new things and to immerse myself into other cultures and perspectives. Reading helps me to be informed and to be a better person in understanding others."

On Saturday, March 7, 2020, West Hall High School hosted the Elementary Regional Science Olympiad. The high school venue proved perfect for the event, and based on tremendous positive feedback from students, parents and coaches, WHHS plans to provide a permanent home for the event. Almost 200 elementary students competed!

Eight schools were represented, and four schools had two teams competing, for a total of twelve teams.Team results were as follows:

1st – Flowery Branch Elementary (Team 1)
2nd – Union County
3rd – Flowery Branch Elementary (Team 2)
4th – McEver Arts Academy
5th - Lula Elementary

The top team will go to the state competition at Kennesaw State University on Saturday, May 9th. This will be the 7th year in a row that Flowery Branch Elementary has made it to the state competition.

Congrats to all the winners and participants, and many thanks to West Hall High School, the local high school students who volunteered, and the students from Georgia Tech who assisted.

Congratulations to Jack Thomas, a junior at Flowery Branch High School; and Erick Villanueva, a junior at East Hall High School, for being selected as delegates for the 2020 Washington Youth Tour. Both will attend an all-expense paid for leadership development experience sponsored by Georgia's electric cooperatives and organized by the National Rural Electric Cooperative Association.

High school counselors and teachers in the Jackson EMC service area were invited to nominate students for the competition, and students could apply directly, as well. Four delegates were selected based on their academics, community service, oral and written communications skills, letters of recommendation, and an interview. The other two Jackson EMC delegates selected were Alex Crabb, a junior at Dacula High School, and Kennedy Turner, a junior at North Gwinnett High School.

Congratulations again to Jack and to Erick, to the other delegates, and many thanks to Jackson EMC for their hand in the sponsorship.

This week's Leading and Reading Spotlight is Clay Hobbs, Director of Transportation for the Hall County School District.

What are you currently reading?

"Crucial Conversations." It is a professional self-help guide to learning the art of effectively communicating with the people in your work environment."

What book is one of your favorites and why?

”Last of the Breed” by Louis L’Amour. The plot was different from most of L’Amour’s work. I couldn’t put it down. I always thought it would make a great movie.

What do you enjoy reading?

"Fiction, because I love a good story!"

Why do you read?

"Many reasons, but mainly to stay informed about the rest of the world. I also try to read the Bible to my son before he goes to bed."

This week's teacher spotlight is Jennifer Carwile, band director and music teacher at North Hall Middle School.

Principal Kristin Finley says of Ms. Carwile:

" Ms. Carwile's love for teaching is apparent in all that she does. With a ready smile, infectious laugh, and quick wit, she is loved and respected by all!"

Why does she teach?

"I love kids and music. Band combines the two! Watching students understand the technical concepts on paper in black and white, and then transfer those markings to something that literally hundreds of people can listen to (and enjoy) is inspiring. Band kiddos make me want to be a better person/teacher every day."

Her favorite quote?

"We are repeatedly what we do. Excellence, then, is not an act, but a habit." Aristotle

This week's Hall County Teacher Spotlight is Mary Stevens from Lula Elementary.

Principal Lynette Scheman has this to say about Ms. Stevens:

"A great teacher can inspire hope, ignite the imagination, and instill a love of learning; that is what Mary Stevens does every day in her classroom. Mary is a 4th grade teacher that has been teaching for 28 years and every day she takes a hand, opens a mind, and touches a heart!"

Why does Ms. Stevens teach?

"I teach for the teachers who truly saw me when I was in school. Those particular teachers, who I can still name today, gave me value and a safe place to land when I had none. I am paying it forward. I simply love what I do every day."

Her favorite quote?

"Remember: everyone in the classroom has a story that leads to misbehavior or defiance. 9 times out of 10, the story behind the misbehavior won’t make you angry. It will break your heart." –Annette Breaux

This week's teacher spotlight is LaChele Brown from East Hall Middle School.

Principal Jeff Chandler says of Ms. Brown:

"LaChele is a great teacher leader who builds great relationships with students and teachers throughout the school and the community. She goes above and beyond to help others."

Why does Ms. Brown teach?

"I teach because I feel that I can make a difference in the lives of our children. Every student has a voice that matters and I want to help shape them into young men and women. I want my students to know that I have their backs and that I support them; however, I have high expectations for each one of them as if they were my own children. I want them to feel that my classroom is a place of safety, compassion, and love."

Ms. Brown's favorite quote?

"Every child deserves a CHAMPION- an adult who will never give up on them--who understands the power of connection and insists that they become the best that they can possibly be." Rita Pierson

This week's Leading and Reading Spotlight is Dr. Jason Carter, Principal at Flowery Branch High School.

What are you currently reading?

"I am currently reading “Hacking Leadership” by Joe Sanfelippo and Tony Sinanis. The book simplifies leadership into 10 different “Hacks.” These Hacks are related to schools and school leadership. The authors break down the hacks into three groups, which are Be Intentional, Open Doors, and Build Staff. The book takes a real practical approach to school leadership. For personal reflection, I am currently reading “Not Forsaken” by Louie Giglio."

What do you enjoy reading?

"I love reading professional books, and non-fiction books. I want to improve as a leader, grow professionally, and grow personally. I like non-fiction because nonfiction tends to motivate you to make practical changes in your thinking process."

Why do you read?

"I read for enjoyment, to learn, and to try to improve as a leader. I also try to set a good example for daughters to be a lifelong learner."

This week's Leading and Reading Spotlight is Chris Foster, West Hall Middle School Assistant Principal.

What are you currently reading?

"I am currently reading FDR: The Beckoning of Destiny 1882 – 1928, by Kenneth S. Davis. This book documents the first half of Franklin Delano Roosevelt’s life, both private, professional, and political."

What book is one of your favorites and why?

"Don’t Stop the Carnival, by Herman Wouk. This book is one my favorites because it serves as a great escape from the mundane. The book revolves around a character (Norman Paperman) who leaves everything to reinvent himself as the owner of a resort on a lush, tropical Caribbean island, something many of us may have daydreamed of doing at some point in our lives."

What do you enjoy reading?

"Political History."

Why do you read?

"I read for enjoyment, to learn, and to relax."

This week's Leading and Reading Spotlight is Chris Skogsberg, Assistant Principal, Cherokee Bluff High School.

What are you currently reading?

"I am currently reading “The Legend of Drizzit: Dark Elf Trilogy” by R.A. Salvatore. The main character is a dark elf who struggles to follow his principles in a world that doesn’t support him."

What do you enjoy reading?

I like reading all genres but Fantasy and Sci-Fi are my favorites. I love the creativity and infinite possibilities that are explored in these books. Many times fantasy stories also explore and resolve issues that we struggle to face in our current reality."

Why do you read?

"I find parts of who I am in every book I read. Each story teaches me a little more about why I think, speak, act, and care the way I do. Books also help me to feel like I am part of a community and let me escape at the same time.""

This week's Leading and Reading is Jennifer Westbrook
Position, Principal, Mt. Vernon Exploratory School.

What book is one of your favorites and why?

"One of my favorite education books is The Innovator’s Mindset by George Couros. Our leadership team read this book, and it aligns well to our school culture. A book I am looking forward to reading soon is another one by George Couros, Innovate Inside the Box."

What do you enjoy reading?

"When I am not reading about leadership and education, I enjoy reading realistic fiction. Karen Kingsbury is one of my favorite authors."

Why do you read?

"I read to learn and I also read for enjoyment. It is exciting that we are growing a new generation of readers in Hall County Schools."

This week’s Leading and Reading Spotlight is Jared Belew, Principal at Spout Springs School of Enrichment

What book is one of your favorites and why?

“The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe by C.S. Lewis is one of my all-time favorite books. It is the perfect mix of childhood fantasy and deeper messaging. The message of hope that the book promotes encourages me greatly since we often live in a world where tragedy and evil seem to overshadow the beautiful and good things about life.”

What do you enjoy reading (genre)?

“I typically move in and out of various genres, but definitely lean toward historical nonfiction. I enjoy learning about the past and how it shapes our present and future world.”

Why do you read?

“I read for both pleasure and information. Reading opens my eyes to new thoughts, ideas, and ways of thinking.”

This week's Hall County Teacher Spotlight is Sarah Cole
from The Academies of Discovery at South Hall Middle School

Principal Joey Millwood's comments on Mrs. Cole:

"Mrs. Cole is a true gem. She loves kids. She loves learning. She does LOTS of both! Her straightforward approach to teaching, along with her ability to meet all students at their point of need, ensures that her students learn and grow. Additionally, she exemplifies servant leadership as she takes new teachers under her wing as well as serving as a friend and mentor for many others."

Why do you teach, Mrs Cole?

“It is a calling from God. I love the challenge of never knowing what each day holds and I live for those “light bulb moments” when kids grasp a concept or master a new skill.”

Mrs. Cole, What’s your favorite quote?

“Shoot for the moon. Even if you miss, you'll land among the stars.” – Norman Vincent Peale
